choices.text: Give another dose of Anti-D 72 h postpartum if the baby’s blood group is Rh positive
Give another dose of Anti-D 72 h postpartum irrespective of baby blood group.
No need of additional dose since she is ICT negative
Given another dose of Anti-D 72 hours postpartum only if ICT is positive

questions.text: A Rh-negative mother, who has Indirect Coombs (ICT), negative was given Anti-D at 28 weeks pregnancy. Which of the following is the correct option regarding Anti-D prophylaxis?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Give another dose of Anti-D 72 h postpartum if the baby’s blood group is Rh positive

 

Prophylaxis:

 

  • Anti D (300 mcg IM) given at 28 weeks (If ICT is negative)
  • Repeated within 72 h after delivery if baby is Rh positive
  • 300 mcg neutralizes 30 ml of fetal blood (15 ml of fetal red cells)
  • Avoid past dates; Avoid methylergometrine
  • Delivery is the cause of 90% of feto maternal haemorrhage
  • Also given after inciting events (When feto maternal haemorrhage can happen)
    • Spontaneous/ induced abortion/ MTP/ fetal demise at any gestation
    • Ectopic pregnancy, Molar pregnancy
    • Selective fetal reduction/ Amniocentesis/ Chorionic villous sampling
    • External cephalic version
    • Manual removal of placenta
    • Abruptio Placentae/ Abdominal trauma

 

Let us look at each option:

 

Option A. Give another dose of Anti-D 72 h postpartum if the baby’s blood group is Rh positive (Correct Answer): If an Rh-negative mother delivers an Rh-positive baby, she is at risk of being sensitized to Rh-positive blood. Administering Anti-D within 72 hours postpartum can prevent Rh immunization in future pregnancies.

 

Option B. Give another dose of Anti-D 72 h postpartum irrespective of baby blood group: incorrect. The need for a postpartum dose of Anti-D depends on the baby's Rh status. If the baby is Rh-negative, the mother's body will not be exposed to Rh-positive antigens, and thus she would not require another dose.

 

Option C. No need for an additional dose since she is ICT negative: incorrect. Being ICT  negative before delivery means the mother has not yet formed antibodies against Rh-positive blood. However, this does not preclude the need for postpartum prophylaxis if the baby is Rh-positive.

 

Option D. Given another dose of Anti-D 72 hours postpartum only if ICT is positive: This statement is incorrect. Anti-D is given postpartum to prevent the mother from developing antibodies, not because she has already developed them. An ICT positive result would indicate that the mother has already been sensitized, which is what the prophylaxis aims to prevent.

 

Educational Objective: The administration of Anti-D prophylaxis to an Rh-negative mother is critical for preventing Rh immunization. If the newborn is Rh-positive, the mother should receive another dose of Anti-D within 72 hours postpartum, irrespective of her ICT status at the time of delivery. This strategy is essential for safeguarding maternal health in subsequent pregnancies.

 

Ref: Page no 305, Williams Obstetrics 25th edition

choices.text: Repeat ICT after 2 weeks
Give steroid cover and deliver
Perform ultrasound assessment including MCA-PSV
Perform intrauterine transfusion

questions.text: A 25-year G2A1 at 28 weeks with blood group B negative gets an ICT done. The report is 1:32. What is the next best step?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Perform ultrasound assessment including MCA-PSV

 

Management of an already sensitized pregnancy (i.e., ICT positive)

 

  • Check ICT monthly till 24 weeks and weekly thereafter till critical titers are reached
  • In ICT, higher titres indicate greater antibody concentration.
  • Critical titre 1:32 > 1:16
  • Once critical titre is reached - Check Peak systolic velocity of Middle cerebral artery (PSV of MCA)
  • If PSV of MCA > 1.5 MoM – Cordocentesis and check fetal Hematocrit (Hct)
  • If Hct of fetal blood is < 30% - Intra uterine transfusion with O negative blood is transfused

 

Let us look at each option:

 

Option A. Repeat ICT after 2 weeks: While repeating the ICT could provide additional information on whether the antibody levels are increasing, it would not give immediate insight into the fetal condition at the time.

 

Option B. Give steroid cover and deliver: Administering steroids and delivering the baby is a course of action for cases where there's evidence of fetal distress or significant maturity, and the pregnancy is at a viable stage. At 28 weeks, unless there's urgent evidence of fetal compromise, immediate delivery is not typically the first step.

 

Option C. Perform ultrasound assessment including MCA-PSV (Correct Answer): Performing an ultrasound to assess the fetus, including the Middle Cerebral Artery Peak Systolic Velocity (MCA-PSV), helps determine if the fetus is anemic. An elevated MCA-PSV is indicative of fetal anemia and may necessitate further interventions. This is a non-invasive way to monitor the fetus and is the next best step in this case.

 

Option D. Perform intrauterine transfusion: This is a treatment for fetal anemia, not a diagnostic step. It would be considered if there's evidence of significant fetal anemia and distress, typically indicated by an abnormal MCA-PSV and other ultrasound findings.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

In a pregnant Rh-negative woman with a positive ICT, the next best step is to perform an ultrasound assessment including MCA-PSV to check for fetal anemia. This approach allows for timely and non-invasive monitoring of the fetus, which is crucial for deciding on further management to prevent fetal morbidity and mortality.

 

Ref: Page no 303, Williams Obstetrics 25th edition

choices.text: Cordocentesis & Intrauterine transfusion (if necessary)
Repeat ICT after 2 weeks.
Give maternal steroid and deliver.
Repeat MCA-PSV after 2 weeks.

questions.text: A 32-year-old G3A2, Rh Negative, pregnant lady presents at 31 weeks pregnancy with an Indirect Coomb’s Test (ICT) titer of 1:64. Ultrasound assessment shows MCA PSV more than 1.5 MOM. What is the next step in management?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Cordocentesis & Intrauterine transfusion (if necessary)

 

Management of an already sensitized pregnancy (i.e., ICT positive)

 

  • Check ICT monthly till 24 weeks and weekly thereafter till critical titers are reached.
  • Critical titer is > 1: 16
  • Once critical titer is reached - Check Peak systolic velocity of Middle cerebral artery (PSV of MCA)
  • If PSV of MCA > 1.5 MoM – Cordocentesis and check fetal Hematocrit (Hct)
  • If Hct of fetal blood is < 30% - Intra uterine transfusion with O negative blood is transfused

 

Let us look at each option:

 

Option A. Cordocentesis & Intrauterine transfusion (if necessary) (Correct Answer): Given the high ICT titer and the ultrasound showing an MCA PSV (Middle Cerebral Artery Peak Systolic Velocity) of more than 1.5 MOM (multiples of the median), there's a high risk of fetal anemia. Cordocentesis (fetal blood sampling) is done to confirm anemia and intrauterine transfusion is performed if necessary. This is the most direct approach to treat potential fetal anemia.

 

Option B. Repeat ICT after 2 weeks: While repeating the ICT might provide information about the progression of the mother's antibody levels, it doesn't address the immediate concern of fetal well-being. Given the current findings, waiting two weeks could result in a delay in essential treatment.

 

Option C. Give maternal steroid and deliver: Administering steroids and delivering the baby is generally considered in cases of fetal distress or when nearing term. At 31 weeks, unless there's urgent evidence of severe fetal compromise, immediate delivery is not typically the first choice.

 

Option D. Repeat MCA-PSV after 2 weeks: Waiting two weeks to repeat the MCA-PSV could delay necessary intervention. The current MCA PSV already indicates a high risk of fetal anemia, necessitating more immediate action.

 

Educational Objective: In cases of suspected fetal anemia due to Rh incompatibility, as indicated by high maternal ICT titers and abnormal MCA PSV, cordocentesis and potential intrauterine transfusion are vital for direct assessment and management of fetal anemia. This approach is crucial in preventing fetal morbidity and mortality associated with severe anemia.

 

Ref: Page no 303, Williams Obstetrics 25th edition

choices.text: MTP at 63 days
Manual removal of placenta
Amniocentesis at 16 weeks
Intrauterine transfusion at 28 weeks

questions.text: Anti-D prophylaxis is required in all the cases except:
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Intrauterine transfusion at 28 weeks

 

  • Anti D (300 mcg IM) given at 28 weeks (If ICT is negative)
  • Repeated within 72 h after delivery if baby is Rh positive
  • 300 mcg neutralizes 30 ml of fetal blood (15 ml of fetal red cells)
  • Avoid past dates; Avoid methyl-ergometrine
  • Delivery is the cause of 90% of feto maternal haemorrhage
  • Also given after inciting events (When feto maternal haemorrhage can happen)
    • Spontaneous/ induced abortion/ MTP/ fetal demise at any gestation
    • Ectopic pregnancy, Molar pregnancy
    • Selective fetal reduction/ Amniocentesis/ Chorionic villous sampling
    • External cephalic version
    • Manual removal of placenta
    • Abruptio Placentae/ Abdominal trauma

 

Let us look at each option :

 

Option A. MTP at 63 days, B. Manual removal of placenta and C. Amniocentesis at 16 weeks can all lead to mixing of fetal and maternal blood. Therefore, Anti-D prophylaxis is recommended for Rh-negative women undergoing these  procedure.

 

Option D. Intrauterine transfusion at 28 weeks: Intrauterine transfusion is performed for the treatment of fetal conditions, often involving direct fetal blood transfusion. It does not typically involve a risk of fetal-maternal blood mixing to the extent that would require Anti-D prophylaxis for the mother. Therefore, Anti-D prophylaxis is generally not required in this scenario.

 

Educational Objective: Anti-D immunoglobulin is vital for preventing Rh sensitization in Rh-negative women in situations where there's a risk of fetal-maternal blood mixing, such as MTP, manual removal of the placenta, and amniocentesis. It is generally not required during intrauterine transfusion as this procedure does not typically involve significant fetal-maternal blood mixing

 

Ref: Page no 305, Williams Obstetrics 25th edition

choices.text: Immediate delivery
Intrauterine transfusion
Repeat amniocentesis after 1 week
Plasmapheresis

questions.text: At 28 weeks gestation amniocentesis reveals ∆ OD 450 in Liley's zone 3. Which of the following is the best line of management?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Intrauterine transfusion

 

  • Management of an already sensitized pregnancy (i.e., ICT positive)
    • Check ICT monthly till 24 weeks and weekly thereafter till critical titers are reached.
    • Critical titer is > 1: 16
    • Once critical titer is reached - Check Peak systolic velocity of Middle cerebral artery (PSV of MCA)
    • If PSV of MCA > 1.5 MoM – Cordocentesis and check fetal Hematocrit (Hct)
    • If Hct of fetal blood is < 30% - Intra uterine transfusion with O negative blood is transfused
    • Earlier, amniotic fluid spectrophotometry was done to determine the level of bilirubin in the amniotic fluid (indirectly assessing anemia) by spectrophotometry (bilirubin peaks at a wavelength of 450 nm). This value is then plotted on Liley’s graph. (> 27 weeks) or Queenans graph (< 27 weeks)
      • Zone 1 & lower level of zone 2: Repeat Amniocentesis after 2 weeks
      • Upper zone 2: Cordocentesis and Intra-uterine transfusion if Hct < 30%
      • Zone 3: cordocentesis and Intra-uterine transfusion

 

Let us look at each option:

 

Option A. Immediate delivery: Delivering the baby at 28 weeks poses significant risks due to prematurity. Immediate delivery is typically considered when the fetus is at a viable gestational age and if intrauterine interventions are not possible or have failed.

 

Option B. Intrauterine transfusion (Correct Answer): A Δ OD 450 in Liley's zone 3 indicates severe fetal anemia. Intrauterine transfusion is the preferred treatment for severe fetal anemia, especially at a gestational age where the fetus is not yet viable for delivery. This procedure involves transfusing blood directly to the fetus and can significantly improve fetal condition.

 

Option C. Repeat amniocentesis after 1 week: Given that Liley's zone 3 represents severe fetal anemia, waiting another week without intervention could lead to worsening of the fetal condition.

 

Option D. Plasmapheresis: Plasmapheresis is a procedure used to remove antibodies from the mother's blood. While it can be used in cases of immune-mediated diseases, it is not the first-line treatment for fetal anemia indicated by Liley's zone 3 findings. The efficacy of plasmapheresis in changing pregnancy outcomes in Rh isoimmunization is not conclusively established. Its use is limited to certain cases where the potential benefits outweigh the risks and complexities of the procedure.

 

Educational Objective: In cases where amniocentesis reveals Δ OD 450 in Liley's zone 3, indicating severe fetal anemia, the best line of management is intrauterine transfusion. This intervention directly addresses the fetal anemia, providing immediate treatment to improve fetal health and outcome.

 

Ref: Page no 303, Williams Obstetrics 25th edition

choices.text: Anti – D prophylaxis should be given following delivery.
Anti -D prophylaxis should be given as soon as possible only if she has not received Anti-D prophylaxis at 28 weeks.
Anti-D prophylaxis should be given as soon as possible even if she has received Anti-D prophylaxis at 28 weeks.
Anti-D prophylaxis is not required.

questions.text: A 34-year primigravida presents at 34 weeks with mild spotting. She is not in labor and the ultrasound shows the placenta in the upper segment. On evaluation, her blood group is B -negative and her husband is Rh positive. What is true regarding Anti – D prophylaxis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Anti-D prophylaxis should be given as soon as possible even if she has received Anti-D prophylaxis at 28 weeks.

 

(Ref: Page no 305, Williams Obstetrics 25th edition)

 

  • Prophylaxis:
    • Anti D (300 mcg IM) given at 28 weeks (If ICT is negative)
    • Repeated within 72 h after delivery if baby is Rh positive
    • 300 mcg neutralizes 30 ml of fetal blood (15 ml of fetal red cells)
    • Avoid past dates; Avoid methylergometrine
    • Delivery is the cause of 90% of feto maternal haemorrhage
    • Also given after inciting events (When feto maternal haemorrhage can happen)
    • Dose: 50 mcg < 12 weeks and 300 mcg if > 12 weeks

 

Inciting events:

 

 

Let us look at each option:

 

Option A. Anti-D prophylaxis should be given following delivery: While it's true that Anti-D is routinely given postpartum, this option overlooks the immediate need due to the current bleeding episode.

 

Option B. Anti-D prophylaxis should be given as soon as possible only if she has not received Anti-D prophylaxis at 28 weeks: This option is not accurate because the need for Anti-D prophylaxis in the event of antepartum bleeding is independent of whether she received prophylaxis at 28 weeks.

 

Option C. Anti-D prophylaxis should be given as soon as possible even if she has received Anti-D prophylaxis at 28 weeks (Correct Answer): This is the correct approach. The woman should receive Anti-D prophylaxis as soon as possible following the bleeding episode, regardless of her having received a routine dose at 28 weeks. Each episode of potential fetal-maternal hemorrhage, such as bleeding in pregnancy, warrants a dose of Anti-D.

 

Option D. Anti-D prophylaxis is not required: This is incorrect. Given the woman’s Rh-negative status and the occurrence of antepartum bleeding, Anti-D prophylaxis is necessary.

 

Educational Objective: Rh-negative pregnant women should receive Anti-D prophylaxis following any antepartum bleeding event to prevent Rh sensitization, regardless of prior prophylaxis at 28 weeks.

 

Ref: Page no 305, Williams Obstetrics 25th edition)

choices.text: Kleihauer Betke test
Rosette test
Peripheral smear
Flow cytometry

questions.text: A 32-year Rh negative woman had a normal delivery following which the following test was done. What is this test?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Kleihauer Betke test

 

  • Tests for feto-maternal haemorrhage are:
    1. Rosette test (Qualitative estimation)
    2. Kleihauer Betke test (acid elution test)
    3. Flow cytometry

 

Let us look at each option :

 

Option A. Kleihauer-Betke Test: This test is performed to detect feto-maternal haemorrhage .On a microscope slide maternal blood is smeared and treated with an acid solution. The acid elutes (washes out) the adult hemoglobin, leaving only the fetal red blood cells which contain fetal hemoglobin intact. These fetal cells appear as bright pink or red against a pale background. The contrast makes them easy to identify and count under a microscope.

 

Option B. Rosette Test: The Rosette test is a rapid, qualitative assay for feto-maternal haemorrhage. It involves mixing the mother's blood with anti-D (Rh) antibodies. If fetal Rh-positive cells are present in an Rh-negative mother's blood, they form rosettes around the anti-D coated red blood cells. These rosettes can be observed microscopically as clusters of cells.

 

Option C. Peripheral Smear: A drop of blood is spread thinly on a slide and typically stained with Wright’s or Giemsa stain. Under the microscope, red blood cells appear as round, flat discs, white blood cells have varying shapes with distinct nuclei, and platelets look like small dots. It is used to diagnose a range of blood disorders. However, it is not specifically used for detecting fetal-maternal hemorrhage .

 

Option D. Flow Cytometry: Flow cytometry doesn't produce a traditional image but rather generates a flow cytometric plot or graph. Cells or particles are tagged with fluorescent markers and passed through a laser beam, they scatter light and emit fluorescence. The resulting data are plotted on graphs, with each dot representing a cell or particle.

 

Educational Objective: The Kleihauer-Betke test is essential for detecting fetal red blood cells in the maternal circulation, especially in Rh-negative women post-delivery, to assess the need for appropriate Anti-D prophylaxis. This test helps in quantifying fetal-maternal hemorrhage and guides the management of Rh incompatibility

 

Ref: Page no 307, Williams Obstetrics 25th edition

choices.text: Anterior cerebral artery
Middle cerebral artery
Posterior cerebral artery
Umbilical artery

questions.text: Doppler of this fetal artery is useful in diagnosing fetal anemia
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Middle cerebral artery

 

  • Doppler of the Middle cerebral artery is used for diagnosing anemia in Rh iso-immunized pregnancies.

 

Let us look at each option:

 

Option A. Anterior cerebral artery: Doppler studies of the anterior cerebral artery are generally used to assess cerebral perfusion and can indicate changes in brain blood flow

 

Option B. Middle cerebral artery (Correct Answer): Doppler ultrasound of the middle cerebral artery (MCA) is a key tool in diagnosing fetal anemia. The peak systolic velocity (PSV) in the MCA increases in anemic fetuses due to reduced blood viscosity and compensatory mechanisms to increase oxygen delivery to the brain.

 

Option C. Posterior cerebral artery:  Its Doppler study is more relevant to cerebral vascular physiology and pathology but not specifically for anemia.

 

Option D. Umbilical artery: Doppler studies of the umbilical artery are crucial for assessing placental and fetal blood flow, particularly in cases of suspected placental insufficiency. While important for fetal well-being, it is not the primary tool for diagnosing fetal anemia.

 

Educational Objective: Doppler ultrasound of the middle cerebral artery is a valuable non-invasive tool for diagnosing fetal anemia. MCA Doppler is particularly useful because the peak systolic velocity increases in anemia, providing an indirect but reliable indicator of the condition. This technique is essential for guiding management in cases of suspected fetal anemia, especially due to conditions like Rh isoimmunization

 

Ref: Page no 303, Williams Obstetrics 25th edition

choices.text: Arrange for cordocentesis and consider Intra uterine transfusion if PCV < 30%
Give Betamethasone for fetal lung maturity and deliver.
Amniocentesis for amniotic fluid spectrophotometry
Repeat a PSV of the MCA after  2 weeks

questions.text: A 25-year G3P2 presented to the Antenatal clinic at 28 weeks. Her blood group is B neg and her partners blood group is B +. Indirect Coombs test revealed high titers and an MCA revealed an increased diastolic flow > 1.5 MoM with a normal peak systolic velocity. Which of the following is correct?
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Repeat a PSV of the MCA after 2 weeks

 

  • In the scenario given, it is mentioned that the peak systolic velocity (PSV) is normal.
  • The patient needs to be followed up.
  • Only when the PSV> 1.5 MoM; should a cordocentesis be done

 

Let us look at each option:

 

Option A. Arrange for cordocentesis and consider intrauterine transfusion if PCV < 30%: Cordocentesis is a procedure to obtain fetal blood and assess hematocrit (PCV). Intrauterine transfusion is considered if fetal anemia is confirmed. However, this step might be premature if only the diastolic flow in the MCA is increased, and the peak systolic velocity (PSV) is normal. Cordocentesis carries risks and is typically considered when there's clear evidence of fetal anemia.

 

Option B. Give Betamethasone for fetal lung maturity and deliver: Administering Betamethasone and planning for delivery would be considered if there's evidence of significant fetal compromise and the pregnancy is at a stage where delivery is viable. At 28 weeks, unless there is urgent evidence of severe fetal distress, immediate delivery is not typically the first choice.

 

Option C. Amniocentesis for amniotic fluid spectrophotometry: Amniotic fluid spectrophotometry is used to measure bilirubin levels, which can indicate fetal hemolysis. However, with the advent of non-invasive methods like MCA Doppler, its use has decreased

 

Option D. Repeat a PSV of the MCA after 2 weeks (Correct Answer): Since the peak systolic velocity of the MCA is normal, indicating no immediate severe fetal anemia, monitoring with a repeat MCA Doppler in 2 weeks is a prudent approach.

 

Educational Objective: In cases of suspected fetal anemia due to Rh incompatibility, monitoring with repeated MCA Doppler studies is crucial, especially when initial findings are borderline or inconclusive. This approach allows for close surveillance of the fetus and helps in deciding the appropriate time for interventions like cordocentesis or intrauterine transfusion.

 

Ref: Page no 303, Williams Obstetrics 25th edition

choices.text: 350 nm
400 nm
450 nm
500 nm

questions.text: On amniotic fluid spectrophotometry, optical density of bilirubin peaks at a wavelength of?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. 450 nm

 

  • On spectrophotometry, bilirubin levels peak at an optical density wavelength of 450 nm

 

Bilirubin in amniotic fluid has a peak absorption at around 450 nm, which is in the blue region of the visible spectrum. This characteristic peak is used in spectrophotometry to assess the level of bilirubin and, by extension, the degree of fetal hemolysis. Thus option A) is correct.

 

Educational Objective: In amniotic fluid spectrophotometry, bilirubin, an indicator of fetal hemolysis, peaks at an optical density of 450 nm. This knowledge is essential in assessing the severity of fetal hemolytic disease, such as in cases of Rh incompatibility, and guides subsequent management decisions.

 

Ref: Page no 304, Williams Obstetrics 25th edition

choices.text: O positive
Irradiated
Leukocyte poor
80% PCV

questions.text: All are features of the blood transfused in intra-uterine blood transfusion except?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. O positive

 

Intra-uterine transfusion is done using: Red cells which are:

 

  • Freshly donated
  • O neg
  • CMV neg
  • 80% PCV
  • Irradiated
  • Leukocyte poor

 

Let us look at each option:

 

Option A. O positive (Answer): O positive blood is not typically used for intrauterine transfusion, especially if the fetus is Rh negative. The ideal blood type for intrauterine transfusion is O negative, RhD negative, to avoid Rh sensitization and other blood type incompatibilities.

 

Option B. Irradiated: Blood used in intrauterine transfusions should be irradiated. This prevents transfusion-associated graft-versus-host disease, a rare but serious complication.

 

Option C. Leukocyte poor: The blood should be leukocyte poor (or leuko-reduced), meaning that white blood cells are removed. This reduces the risk of febrile non-hemolytic transfusion reactions and CMV transmission.

 

Option D. 80% PCV: Blood for intrauterine transfusions is often concentrated to a hematocrit (PCV, packed cell volume) of about 80% to deliver a higher amount of red blood cells in a smaller volume, which is necessary due to the limited space in the fetal circulation.

 

Educational Objective: For intrauterine blood transfusions, the ideal blood type is O negative, RhD negative, and the blood should be irradiated and leukocyte poor, with a high packed cell volume (about 80%). These specifications are critical to ensure the safety and effectiveness of the transfusion for the fetus

 

Ref: Page no 304, Williams Obstetrics 25th edition

choices.text: Trisomy 18
Turner syndrome
Klinefelter syndrome
Trisomy 13

questions.text: The most common aneuploidy causing non-immune hydrops is?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Turner syndrome

 

Etiology for non immune hydrops:

 

  •  
  • Aneuploidy (20%) – MC: 45 XO (Turner Syndrome)
  • Cardiovascular (15%)
  • Infections (15%) –Most common – Parvovirus B19

 

Let us look at each option:

 

Option A. Trisomy 18: It is also known as Edwards syndrome ,it is associated with a high rate of fetal anomalies and mortality. While it can cause hydrops, it is not the most common aneuploidy leading to this condition.

 

Option B. Turner Syndrome (Correct Answer): Turner syndrome, characterized by a missing or structurally altered X chromosome, is the most common aneuploidy associated with non-immune hydrops fetalis. Common features include lymphatic dysplasia, which can lead to fluid accumulation and hydrops.

 

Option C. Klinefelter Syndrome: Klinefelter syndrome is a genetic condition affecting males, where they have an extra X chromosome (XXY). It is not typically associated with non-immune hydrops fetalis as the most common cause.

 

Option D. Trisomy 13: Trisomy 13, or Patau syndrome, is a severe chromosomal abnormality with multiple anomalies. Like Trisomy 18, it can be associated with hydrops, but it is not the most common cause.

 

Educational Objective: Turner syndrome is the most common aneuploidy causing non-immune hydrops fetalis.

 

Ref: Page no 309, Williams Obstetrics 25th edition

choices.text: CMV
Herpes
Parvovirus B19
Toxoplasma

questions.text: The most common infectious cause of non-immune hydrops is:
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Parvovirus B19

 

Etiology:

 

  • Aneuploidy (20%) – MC: 45 XO (Turner Syndrome)
  • Cardiovascular (15%)
  • Infections (15%) –Most common – Parvovirus B19

 

Let us look at each option:

 

Option A. CMV (Cytomegalovirus): CMV is a common virus that can infect people of all ages. While it can cause congenital infections and may result in complications in pregnancy, it is not the most common infectious cause of non-immune hydrops.

 

Option B. Herpes: Herpes simplex virus can lead to severe complications in newborns if transmitted during childbirth, but it's not typically associated with non-immune hydrops fetalis as the most common cause.

 

Option C. Parvovirus B19 (Correct Answer): Parvovirus B19, the virus responsible for causing fifth disease (erythema infectiosum), is the most common infectious cause of non-immune hydrops fetalis. It can lead to severe anemia in the fetus, which in turn can cause heart failure and hydrops.

 

Option D. Toxoplasma: Toxoplasmosis, caused by the parasite Toxoplasma gondii, is a concern during pregnancy as it can lead to congenital infections. However, it is not the most common infectious cause of non-immune hydrops fetalis.

 

Educational Objective: Parvovirus B19 is the most common infectious cause of non-immune hydrops fetalis.

 

Ref: Page no 309, Williams Obstetrics 25th edition

choices.text: Fluid in all 3 compartments
Fluid in 1 out of 3 compartments
Fluid in 2 out of 3 compartments
Scalp edema and placentomegaly

questions.text: Hydrops fetalis is diagnosed on ultrasound by:
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Fluid in 2 out of 3 compartments

 

Hydrops Fetalis

 

  • Excessive accumulation of serous fluid
  • USG Diagnosis: 2 or more fetal effusions OR 1 effusion + anasarca
  • Usually accompanied with skin edema and placentomegaly
    • USG – clinically significant edema: > 5 mm
    • USG - > 4 cm in 2nd trimester/> 6 cm in the 3rd trimester
  • 2 causes:
    • Immune (Rh iso-immunization) – 10%
    • Non – Immune – 90%

 

Let us look at each opion :

 

Option A. Fluid in all 3 compartments: While finding fluid in all three fetal compartments (such as ascites, pleural effusion, and pericardial effusion) is highly indicative of hydrops fetalis, this level of fluid accumulation is not necessary to make the diagnosis.

 

Option B. Fluid in 1 out of 3 compartments: Fluid accumulation in just one fetal compartment may not be sufficient for the diagnosis of hydrops fetalis. Other causes can lead to isolated fluid accumulations, such as chylothorax or isolated ascites.

 

Option C. Fluid in 2 out of 3 compartments (Correct Answer): The diagnosis of hydrops fetalis is typically made when there is fluid accumulation in two or more different fetal compartments. This can include ascites, pleural effusion, pericardial effusion, skin edema (anasarca), or a combination of these.

 

Option D. Scalp edema and placentomegaly: While scalp edema (often seen as skin thickening) and placentomegaly (enlarged placenta) are common findings in hydrops fetalis, they alone are not sufficient for diagnosis.

 

Educational Objective: Hydrops fetalis is diagnosed on ultrasound when there is fluid accumulation in two or more fetal compartments.

 

Ref: Page no 309, Williams Obstetrics 25th edition

choices.text: 10%
15%
30%
40%

questions.text: Fetal hydrops develops when the hematocrit is less than:
questions.solution:
Ans. B. 15%

 

  • Hydrops develops when the hematocrit < 15%
  • Intrauterine transfusion is indicated when the hematocrit < 30%

 

Fetal hydrops is characterized by the accumulation of fluid in fetal compartments and tissues. It's often associated with severe anemia.

 

Fetal hydrops is likely to develop when the fetal hematocrit falls below 15%because  at this level, the blood's ability to carry oxygen is significantly compromised, leading to heart failure and fluid accumulation in fetal tissues and body cavities.

 

Educational Objective: Fetal hydrops, a condition marked by widespread fluid accumulation in the fetus, commonly develops when the fetal hematocrit falls below 15%.

 

Ref: Page no 305, Williams Obstetrics 25th edition

choices.text: Corticosteroids and delivery
Plan cordocentesis and intrauterine transfusion if the Hct < 30%
Repeat MCA Doppler after 1 week
Repeat ICT after 1 week

questions.text: A 34-year-old G3A2 presents at 31 weeks. She is Rh negative and her ICT is 1:32. An MCA Doppler reveals a PSV less than 1.5 MoM. What will be the next step in management?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Repeat MCA Doppler after 1 week

 

  • Management of an already sensitized pregnancy (i.e., ICT positive)
    • Check ICT monthly till 24 weeks and weekly thereafter till critical titers are reached
    • Critical titre is > 1: 16
    • Once critical titre is reached - Check Peak systolic velocity of Middle cerebral artery (PSV of MCA)
    • If PSV of MCA > 1.5 MoM – Cordocentesis and check fetal Hematocrit (Hct)
    • If Hct of fetal blood is < 30% - Intra uterine transfusion with O negative blood is transfused
  • In this patient, the PSV of the MCA is < 1.5 MoM, so repeat monitoring of MCA PSV is required.

 

Let us look at each option :

 

Option A. Corticosteroids and delivery: Considered when there is evidence of fetal distress or severe fetal compromise, and the fetus is at a gestational age where delivery is feasible. In this case, since the MCA Doppler is not indicative of severe fetal anemia, immediate corticosteroids and delivery may not be necessary.

 

Option B. Plan cordocentesis and intrauterine transfusion if the Hct < 30%: Cordocentesis is a procedure to test fetal blood and is typically considered when there's evidence of fetal anemia or distress. Intrauterine transfusion would be indicated if fetal anemia is confirmed on MCA dopler.

 

Option C. Repeat MCA Doppler after 1 week (Correct Answer): Given that the current MCA Doppler reading is less than 1.5 MoM, indicating no immediate severe fetal anemia, the best course is to monitor the fetal condition closely. Repeating the MCA Doppler after 1 week allows for ongoing assessment of the fetal status and timely intervention if the situation changes.

 

Option D. Repeat ICT after 1 week: While monitoring the ICT can provide information on the progression of the mother’s antibody levels, it does not directly assess the fetal condition.

 

Educational Objective: In cases where an Rh-negative woman has a positive ICT but the fetal MCA Doppler PSV is less than 1.5 MoM, indicating no immediate severe fetal anemia, the best management approach is to closely monitor the fetal condition with repeated MCA Doppler assessments. This strategy allows for timely detection and intervention if fetal anemia develops.

 

Ref: Page no 303, Williams Obstetrics 25th edition
